item.title: The ideal 'T' shaped person myth
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: My first introduction to the idea of the 'T' shaped person was about three years ago. Rob Woodbury was talking at the 2007 SG conference in New York. I've thought that it was a great metaphor for describing people, a kind of personality synaesthesia. Being the obtuse weirdo I am I started to think about other shapes of people. The obvious things that come to mind are the thickness of the top of the T, or if the leg gets really pointy at the end. Then I pretty much forgot about it for a while. Recently I was reading a book about mountaineering, and the section on what to if there is lightening was interesting. http://www.overcomingbias.com/2010/04/all-big-questions-or-none.html herbert simon - time on task rob woodbury - unfair pounce 2xT = spark pure T allows no internal spark

item.title: Tea service
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Last week I got up, made myself some breakfast, then went downstairs to Room 10 and had a coffee, and went to get my hair cut. I'm in the terminal stages of going bald so I've been splashing out on hair cuts because over my whole life I'll be spending next to nothing on haircare. When I arrived at Our Place I was offered a cup of tea. Like any self respecting Englishman I accepted. Clive is from somewhere near Cambridge I think, so it feels like some sort of expatriate solidarity to take tea. A few minutes later I was brought a plunger of lovely looking tea, a little jug of milk, some sugar sachets and a cup. Having just come from a place where if you order a take away coffee they even put the sugar in for you, this started my mind rumbling. So as Clive was washing my hair (more of a token activity as there is so little of it) I started thinking... In general service industries take away things that get in between you and your goal. In the case of the take away coffee, your goal is to get coffee into your mouth as soon as you can; faffing about with putting the sugar in is a faff that can be avoided by a 'value add' by a good barista. So what is it about tea service that sets it apart from this trend? There are a few obvious answers, but none of them is very satisfactory on their own, and there might be some semblance of an answer lurking in between them all.
  • The ceremony of tea service is at least as important as the consumable end product. Tea has a long history of being prepared as an elaborate process, and that process has been infused with meaning (no pun intended). Over time we (our society) have forgotten what that meaning is, but we still remember that there is meaning even if we don't know what it is (is this what philosophers would call normative pressure?). I think that this falls down as a way of explaining the prevalence of tea's complicated serving method because the provision of many other drinks and services have a lot of ceremony in their history, and that seems to have fallen away. In the traditional Japanese tea ceremony the tea is prepared by the tea master, and served to the guests. The guests do very little in the actual preparation. This is pretty similar to the Ethiopian coffee preparation ceremony that starts with green beans and ends several hours later with a cup. Neither require the guest to make the drink. So how did the tea ceremony get comodified, but coffee totally lost it's history? [Needs a bit of work!]
  • Tea needs to visually show off it's quality
  • Tea is a personal thing, and needs to be made to a very exact specification. This one is particularly odd. Being able to make tea for someone you know is a very intimate thing; it implies that you know them and their tastes. This sounds like a good reason for leaving the last steps of the tea prep to the drinker, but that rationale could apply to a lot of services, and usually the reason that you'd go to someone who would provide a service is that they can do it better than we can. Surely someone professional can make an awesome cup of tea, so it can't be their ability to make it specificaly to our tastes or we'd develop a better vocabulary for ordering tea.
  • The most convincing argument for the coffee-tea argument is that most coffee we have now is espresso, and espresso has only been around since the second world war, whereas the tea making process of putting leaves in water is much older. Because espresso requires special machinery it is
None of these reasons really explain why

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Ben Doherty 30th May 2009 This script is a horrific hack. Free SketchUp has no export capacity for models, but it can be asked to save a file in a specific location by a ruby script. Microstation can reference an SKP file, and it can also export several types of other file. (dxf, dwg, collada etc.)as long as you know how to modify the microstation key in part of the script file output. This script just shortcuts that, and makes it do it all in one go. {{SyntaxHighlighter:Header}}
require 'sketchup' require 'FileUtils'
UI.menu("PlugIns").add_item("export to dxf noUI"){ exportToDXF }
def exportToDXF #Change the following paths and file names to suit your setup #this will be the name of the final output dxf dxfName = "myExportedDXF"
#this is the path to where your microstation is located, #you must use / forward slashes, not backslashes msExePath = "C:/dev/ms08110758en/app/MicroStation/ustation.exe"
#this is the path to where your empty 3d microstation file is located blankDgnPath = "C:/Program Files/Google/Google SketchUp 6/Plugins/"
#this is the name of your empty 3d microstation file dgnName = "toDXFblank.dgn"
#This is a working directory, don't wory about this scriptPath = "C:/modusScripts/exportToDxfFromSkp/" skpPath = "C:/modusScripts/exportToDxfFromSkp/"
#Don't change anything below this line #******************************************************************************* #checks to see if the temp directory is there, and makes it if it isn't FileUtils.mkdir_p skpPath #save current sketchup file #un-comment in sketchup 7 #Sketchup.active_model.name = dxfName #un comment in sketchup 7 model = Sketchup.active_model skpName = dxfName#model.name #swap with comment in sketchup 7 totalName = skpPath+skpName+".skp" if File.exist? (totalName) #this ensures that there is a fresh file File.delete(totalName) end puts "about to save "+ totalName status = model.save totalName
scriptName = "exportDXF.txt" #fileWhereabouts = scriptPath+scriptName #puts "fileWhereabouts"+fileWhereabouts File::open(scriptPath+scriptName, "w") do |f| #If you really know what you are doign with microstation, #then you can edit this section. It writes a text file that has #key in commands that tell microstation to open an empty file, #attatch the skp file as a reference, exports a dxf, detatched #the references, and then closes microstation #'f' is the file, #the << bit writes to that file #the n is a new line #you need a new line to separate the commands #You can add new commands by saying f<<"keyinCommand"
#REFERENCE ATTACH [configuration_variable:] [,model_name] [,logical_name] [,description] [,view_name] [,scale] [,nesting] [,ON|OFF] ra = "REFERENCE ATTACH "+skpPath+totalName+", default,,,*" #" around the path allows for spaces in path f << ra ex = "nEXPORT DXF "+skpPath+dxfName+'.dxf' #exports the attatched skp as a dxf, and an empty dxf f << ex f << "nREFERENCE DETACH ALL" f << "nEXIT" end
#This command opens microstation, with a given seed file, and then runs #a script file as son as it's started up #microstation exe file [space] file path [space] -Sscript.txt path system (msExePath+' "'+blankDgnPath+dgnName+'" -S'+scriptPath+scriptName)
puts 'finished' end
{{SyntaxHighlighter:BrushesList}}
[[Category:SyntaxHighlighter]] [[Category:SyntaxHighlighter:Brushes]]

item.title: It seems that I am unable to have sex with a dolphin!
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I thought that I'd do something a bit special for my 200th post. It seems that dolphins are in a very small minority[1. The view that the set of species that has sex for pleasure is small is disputed, by wikipedia of all places!  I'm inclined to agree] in the animal kingdom in that they have sex for pleasure[2. anal, oral, vaginal and blowhole sex according to the Museum of Sex].
Law in this country is very clear cut, unusually so. Section 69 (lol) of the Sexual Offences Act 2003 covers "Intercourse with an animal"
  1. A person commits an offence if—
    1. he intentionally performs an act of penetration with his penis,
    2. what is penetrated is the vagina or anus of a living animal, and
    3. he knows that, or is reckless as to whether, that is what is penetrated.
  2. A person (A) commits an offence if—
    1. A intentionally causes, or allows, A’s vagina or anus to be penetrated,
    2. the penetration is by the penis of a living animal, and
    3. A knows that, or is reckless as to whether, that is what A is being penetrated by.
Punishment is up to 2 years imprisonment (it used to be life) Pornographic material involving the same acts are also prohibited by Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 in the controversial 'extreme pornographic material' section. Its pretty draconian: The prohibition is on images showing: "a person performing or appearing to perform an act of intercourse or oral sex with an animal (whether dead or alive), and a reasonable person looking at the image would think that any such person or animal was real." Sentience and consent are dead issues, animals at law cannot consent to intercourse with humans, however, contrast that with vivisection or breeding. Seems to me to be very hypocritical that some primates (admittedly not great apes) can be lobotomised and dog breeders can force their bitches to become pregnant but a loving farmer can't have sex with his flock. A lacuna in the law Ben.

item.title: UNSW arch comp grad projects
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
If you are reading this on Facebook then click here to go to the civilised version, out there in the wild wild west of the internets; it looks nicer.
UNSW's Arch comp course students need to find a 'real' client for their final project. I mentioned before that I had one student, but now I'm lucky enough to be supervising three this semester! They are chronicling their work here, but the general gist of things is that Jen is doing AR, Mike is doing caves, and Jay is doing Kinnect UIs. I've explained their work in terms of the technology that they are using, which is exactly what I've asked them to do! I've asked them to frame their research in terms of an architectural question that they can try to answer by using a technological approach. I've also asked for some kind of empirical metric of efficacy for this approach vs the status quo.

item.title: The myth of the 'T' shaped person
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: Some posts take longer to come to fruition than others, and I think that so far, this one is the longest! In 2007 at the Smart Geometry Conference in New York at Cooper Union, Rob Woodbury gave a talk about the T shaped person. He was relating the concept, borrowed from..., that in order to be a good computational designer you needed to exhibit a T shaped skill profile. The idea is that you have a broad base of skills, and then a deep understanding of your chosen subject; something like having a well rounded education in everything, and a PhD in making molecular nano machines that are specifically for making smiley faces out of DNA. So your broad general knowledge is the top of your T and your deep knowledge of tiny factories is the leg. The idea was (and I must apologise to Rob if I misrepresent him; it was a very long time ago) that you needed to know a fair bit about being an architect, and a hell of a lot about being a programmer. At the time I thought that this argument had a lot going for it, but then eventually something started niggling at me - it was the fact that Rob wasn't T shaped, and neither were any of the other people who I thought were useful and interesting. rob is a two pronger time on task, mastery etc...

item.title: Drink driving...
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: I'm creeping along, trying to second guess the car in front as they weave about, they're indicating right even though there isn't anywhere to go - this person must be drunk. But it's 11am on a week day. Having a motorbike makes one acutely aware of all the ways that other road users can try to kill you. Mostly through having poor awareness of their environment or having slow reaction times. The assailant in the first paragraph wasn't drunk, well I doubt they were, but they were dealing with a car full of rowdy kids. It set me wondering, did it matter why someone's performance as a road-co-user is impaired or just that it is? Why do we pick on drunk people driving cars so enthusiastically? Seems like a measurement issue. It's easy to test if someone is drunk and they will continue to be drunk for the rest of their journey. If they are on the phone or dealing with rowdy kids then they, at the point of testing, will probably not be displaying signs of decreased driving ability. There's also no way I can think of to measure if people are just bad drivers; do they use their wing mirrors, do they care about the other people on the road. This all makes sense to me, the legal system only allows for things that are easy and fairly unambiguous to catch, so it's probably not really worth going after people driving in a hazy bubble of air-con and Britney Spears. What surprises me is that there isn't a stronger normative bias against being a car-texter[1. NSW seems to be pretty into telling people not to text in the car, as is the Economist] or distracted parent[1. Distracted parents can be pretty fatal.]. I'm pretty sure if my friends thought that I drove drunk then a fair few of them would stop being my friend, but they'd probably mind a lot less if they thought that every so often I check my phone[1. I don't do either of these things, if I could get my phone out and take my glove off between gear shifts it'd be a complete miracle!]. I've heard people talk about how little they use their wing mirrors, and parents complaining about their kids unruliness in social situations without rebuke. Why don't these things end up as social norms, frowned upon as hazards to the safety of others as drinking? I wonder if it's because there's no explicit law? If a technological way of checking your alertness, reaction time, general awareness etc. could be found, would we be into it? Would we drop explicit laws that say that driving drunk is statistically a bad idea, and say that if you are able to operate above a certain threshold then you are free to operate your vehicle? I have a feeling that society would be against it, old people, people with slow reactions, people who are tired, distracted or just generally shit drivers would be 'discriminated against', but the road safety stats would support it. My guess is that the compelling rhetoric of anti-discrimination would win over statistical improvement[1. this is a really tricky subject, there are lots of local maxima that would lead to an overall moral coarsening.]. As usual this is more about me writing down questions, but if you have any thoughts I'd love to hear them

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: Now that I'm working 3 days a week I really have no excuse not to me a bit more structured with my scribblings. This morning I started reading Designerly Ways of Knowing by Nigel Cross. People have been telling me that I ought to read it for years[1. mainly Harriet Harris while I was doing my major study], but I've been resistant. Mainly because I'm stubborn but my reasoning was that design was a broad skill that wasn't restricted to any particular field, and especially not to the archi-wankers and graphics-wankers who I'd so frequently heard tell me that they were in some way magical and inscrutable because they were designers. Any hint of self-perceived magicalness makes my skin crawl, so my reaction was to shy away from the book. However, my extremely positive experience (so far at least) in reading The Sciences of the Artificial made me reconsider my position.

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
The skills survey does a whole bunch of things, here's a quick run through of the most important ones.

Training needs

When you have your appraisal you'll go through your skills list and discuss training opportunities with your appraisers. There'll be some discussions along the lines of "You think you're a 3 for Revit, I've done a lot of these appraisal now and you are really much more like an 8!" and so on, but there are also going to be discussions that are "You think you're a 3 for Rhino. Lets make one of your targets to get you to a 7 within 3 months and get you the training you need to get there."

Resourcing

Knowing who's good at what is super helpful for people who are trying to resource a job. The skills are in a big spreadsheet table, so they can just sort to their hearts content and come up with people they didn't know about. The people doing resourcing are pretty knowledgeable about who's good at what, but they can't know everything. By making your skills explicit they can match you to jobs based on skills that they didn't previously know about.  

 Big picture data analysis
This is where my nerdy interest lies. These squiggles below are little line graphs of the data in a few people's results. They are actually the same as the colourful bar chart above, but with a line and not bars. They allow for groupings to be made in a broader way than just on a single variable. The technical term for this is clustering. As a really simple example of this is in the scatter plot below. This is Revit skills plotted on one axis and Health/ science/ lab experience on the other. I can see some vague grouping starting to appear in the way the dots fall. These groups might have some meaning or they might not, but they are worth investigating them by finding out if the names that they belong to fit some kind of group in my mind.   Two dimensional clustering isn't really very useful on most types of data set, but it is easy to understand. I know we are all very proud of our ability to mentally visualise 3d space, but other than a few mathematicians nobody is very good at visualising 4d and up space. Our skills data would need 70 or so mutually perpendicular axes to truly do it justice! Before you totally freak out there is a pretty easy to visualise way to reduce that complexity back to something easy to handle. If you look at the squiggles you'll see that there are obvious similarities to them, for instance the long flat spot corresponds to a natural grouping; non-architectural staff who don't really do the sorts of projects asked in the 'exposure' section. So a very simplified way of thinking about how the computer makes high dimensional clusters is imagining yourself putting squiggles that are like other squiggles together. WHY? Good question. The main reason is that we can use this to identify areas of weakness as a practice. "OMG we don't have anyone who'd be good if a Mars base project came up." So that can inform broad training strategies or hiring. The other thing it can do is help personal development (you'll have to imagine this in 70 dimensional space, I know you can do that!) "You are very similar to this group of people who are all awesome badass ass-kickers, except on these two axes, which are closer to these useless people. Lets get you some training and propel your career into overdrive!!!"

What's wrong with the skills survey the way it is?

To be completely honest, quite a lot. A lot of people have had a pretty big grump at me over the last couple of weeks. The main objection is "but what if my 6 is nothing like their 6" and that's a valid concern. There is no way to really control for that completely, but there are a lot of ways that we can reduce its effects. Our biggest weapon against that is that we (as in the people who use/consume this data) know people personally; that's a big advantage over giant marketing surveys. That means that we can clip braggarts wings and boost up people who are undeservedly harsh on themselves. It's not all subjective though. There are lots of statistical methods that we can use to fix the data that I won't bore you with. (Central limit theorem - AMAZING!!!) There are also lots of other nuanced ways we could make the data collection better. Skills are a fractal thing, the more skilled you become in an area the more new skills you acquire and forget. It'd be crazy to lump a samurai, a chef and a surgeon together because they are all pretty good at working with sharp blades.

What's AMAZING about the skills survey the way it is?

Well, it is a thing, that is, quite literally, infinitely better than it not existing!

∞

There's loads we can do to improve it in the future, but for now, lets get on board and make people's lives (including your own) better.       featured image: http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-4-yQSzGmCC8/T1aNsa6nJJI/AAAAAAAAH00/SWyAy7MC69M/s1600/MapClustering3.png

item.title: tips chest
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I've been collecting things that seem like a good idea. Things that have a lot of upside benefits, but little downside risk. I'm going to use this post as a way to collect these up.

Cheap things (under $50 each)

Mother of pearl buttons: this is a trick from Mr Ogilvie. If you replace all the plastic buttons on a cheapish shirt with mother of pearl, it ends up looking like an expensive shirt. With postage, about $5 on ebay for enough buttons to do all your shirts + about 50c per button to get them sewn on.
Blue blocking glasses: These look a bit gimpy, but block out the blue portion of the light that prevents your pineal gland from producing melatonin[1. I think it's that way around, I can never remember if it stops or starts it, but blue promotes wakefulness.].  I've had mine about a week now and they are already improving my sleep. $7 from amazon or $20 from ebay.
gloves for cooking
Smoked salt and liquid smoke
hello

item.title: Disingenuous
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Whenever I tell people about Posted Notes[1. On one hand Posted Notes is an expensive hobby (with a ratio of income to time spent that would put me somewhere in the bottom billion) but I'm putting a much more positive spin on things and thinking of it as an incredibly low cost education!] they give me one of two responses.
  1. "That is great! Getting letters is lovely but I'm never organised enough to actually send them[1. Although, like me, a lot of people say that they write them and then carry them around until they are so out of date or tatty that they throw them out!]."
  2. "That is the worst! Sending letters is really personal and my aunt Mavis would be devastated if she found out that I'd outsourced sending letters" There isn't really any rebuke to response 2, they are entirely right. When you send a letter to your aunt Mavis you are communicating that you still think about her enough to undertake the logistical marathon of getting a letter into a postbox. I'm not going to argue that you should be using posted notes for that - you shouldn't! The real use for posted notes is to bring a smile to the face of someone who would be happy with an email, but it's a welcome surprise to get something a bit different. Here's a simple way to think about it:
Posted is not there to make your life easier by writing the letters you were going write; it exists to write the letters that you weren't going to write!
All the thank you letters you briefly thought about before you were distracted by more prosaic things, all the Facebook messages that you sent but wished they were more exciting. It's only 789 characters so you can't write a treatise of undying love or argue about who really invented calculus. Remember the content is all yours, all we do is render it visible.

item.title: Who is responsible when ideas are released?
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Without risking becoming too meta, the plan is to try and write a lot more while I'm on this holiday. I have a hunch that when I write, it makes the idea I'm writing about stronger, but also makes a space for more ideas in my brain. Perhaps, ideas aren't like physical material, unable to pack more into a small space. Writing about an idea makes it more well-understood, foundational, able to have new ideas built unto it. It doesn't [inaudible 00:00:28] responsibility for it to the page, if training the mind pulled up the air effortlessly.

Today, I've been mulling over the morality of sharing information. I'm a strong advocate of open [inaudible 00:00:41] context. I don't often see cases where keeping information private or restricting free speech is a benefit. Practical Ethics had a piece on a lady in the USA who is convicted for contempt for refusing to issue marriage certificates to gay couples. They condemned her actions, as I do, but they commended her virtues for standing up for what she believes in. They made a compelling argument that if the opposite had been that we would have held her in high esteem. (I.e. that she had insisted against the law in issuing marriage certificates)

This is almost certainly not the first time someone has noticed good qualities in bad people. Angie Hobbs did a whole History of Ideas on beauty and whether Nazi musicians could make great music (e.g. Hitler is undisputedly an effective orator). Thought I've been mulling over today is the net benefit of sharing that kind of opinion. It would be bad for politician to be seen to endorse the virtue of the trait, but not its expression. The public wouldn’t get the nuance of the point. A subset may even see it as an endorsement of the bad person. Perhaps there are certain ideas that should be controlled. Information about making nuclear or chemical weapons pick up off these techniques.

I'm inclined to think that this sort of information shouldn’t be controlled, but maybe I'll change my mind if I think more about it. It is that now it's just in gun control. Is there a responsibility to present a dangerous idea in a way that renders it safe, or at least as safe as possible? I'm not sure if that's enforceable. Maybe it's not even desirable. Perhaps the responsibility is on the reader to think carefully about how the words are affecting their brain.

The more I think about this, the more I'm sure that it must be a well-discussed topic. I noticed myself using that as a mechanism for not worrying about it. I need to decide if I'm interested in this topic because I enjoy rolling ideas that I've deemed novel around in my head, or is it because I actually want an answer? Perhaps it has no value to me at the moment, but I've laid the foundation to build it up quickly, if I do find a need, like Japan's virtual nuclear weapons capability. I'm going to keep writing and blogging about ideas and my thoughts and I should get at least a basic understanding of the possible positions on this topic: who is responsible when ideas are released?

item.title: What is creativity?
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
This morning's breakfast at Dishoom turned into a pretty wide-ranging discussion on the ethics of killing in video games and how that was going to change when NPCs were more AI than mechanism. Eventually we got onto the subject of what is creativity, which we've been batting around for a few months now. I feel like we made some progress today. I'll try and start from the start.

People who self-label as "creative" annoy me. So do people who self-label as "not creative." The whole concept feels wrong to me. Perhaps I just learned it incorrectly, but I don't think that's the case. I think creating is something to do with bringing new things into the world. That thing needs to be, in some way, novel.

Maybe the first sticking point I came across is a dividing line between creating and producing. What's the difference between creativists and productivity? By dictionary definitions, these two are quite similar; synonymous, even. Modern parlance has elevated creativity to be something to be worshiped and productivity to be something to be nice to have. Productivity is a necessary for being functional in life, but it doesn't have any kind of value judgment. Punching out widgets faster than the next guy is productive, regardless of those widgets' usefulness.

One thing we both agree on is that creativity requires production to exist. Production is the birth of the creativity, or it would remain trapped in the mind womb. People who claim to be creative worry me. Creativity should be obvious in its manifestation. The obvious counterargument to that is that people who work with pure thought stuff might not get the creative label. Newton might not have been regarded as creative if it hadn't been forced to public. Even one whose sole job is to voice ideas can be creative if they speak the idea to another. What isn't creative, in my definition, is to hang out with quirky artistic people. Creativity isn't conferred by socialization.

All this we'd thrashed out on numerous bus-to-work discussions. The new insight from Dishoom is that different jobs have different amounts of the two, almost as a gradient. Some jobs are pure productivity and others are more creative. Mathematics and theoretical physics are the high-creativity version of high-productivity engineering. Philosophy is the high-creativity version of law. I'll see what Seb things of this. I'm still not sure what motivates me to care about this niche definitional issue. Maybe it's that it niggles me, but when that's amplified by how much everyone else seems that someone ought to care about it.

item.title: cheetah
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I've been mulling this idea over for some time now, but it's still poorly formed. What is the right relationship between work and idleness, calm and aggression, et cetera? The source of the idea comes from thinking about carnivores and herbivorous animals. Carnivores seem to have a lot of leisure time. Their food is dense with nutrients, so they can afford to go longer periods between eating. They use this time for idleness and development. Because of the high density of nutrients, they're able to have explosive expenditures of energy to get their next meal.
By contrast, herbivores seem to [actually 00:00:35]. It's also able to be explosively aggressive, charging bulls or antelopes, but those [inaudible 00:00:42] seem to fit our easy picture of their behaviour.
In "Day of the Triffids", one of the characters has a great quote about leisure. Without any great study, leisure seems to be well correlated with progress, whereas periods of [graph 00:00:57] feel stagnant. I may be going off on a tangent here, but it feels like the zen, the [odds most 00:01:03] cycle maintenance concept, the finding calm or peace of mind to be able to perform certain tasks is related.
Leisure is needed to get into the mindset of calm. Excessive business causes a mindset similar to the World War I attitudes that kept sending men over the trenches to their deaths. In this case, we're dealing with a much smaller percentage of human life, but wasting time when time is finite, is just a matter of degree. Being too busy to put the round wheels on because the square ones are okay and we have a deadline to hit, comes up far more often than I ever expected it to. The very fact that people are tired of the axe-sharpening parable shows how common it is.
So I've got an antelope hanging in my tree. Dinner for the next few days is sorted. Now what? There's a star there. There have been articles about outsourcing all domestic work. They feel uncomfortable but I doubt that feeling will last.
A star. I've balanced my sense of calm, of scentedness, of aggression. Meditation seems to be a key part of almost all of [Tim Ferriss' 00:02:12] guests. For more than I expected.
The cheetah has a very simple set of motivations: eat and mate. Perhaps our motivations are the same, but our methods feel more complex. The cheetah's food is our money. A medium to enable freedom. The freedom is the goal, not food or money. This feels like a preachy conclusion, and perhaps the result isn't the important part. It's more of a mindset, being idly ready, [inaudible 00:02:40] busy, or plainly lazy - it's the way to be.
I was going to make this into a Toastmaster speech, but it needs a bit more thought. Perhaps I could talk about cheetahs, cows and pandas and about why it's best to be an apex predator. About the importance of leisure. Turning my usual thought explosion into an imperative statement is my greatest challenge at the moment.

item.title: sagrada
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
All the romance of living on a boat has worn off. After three nights of almost no sleep, we're both like zombies.

We just went around the inside of the Sagrada Familia. It's overwhelming and it's made more so by one's inner ears, when one's inner ears are playing tricks. It's probably the last cathedral that will be built as a multi-generational devotional project. Maybe the last project at all that's motivated by something other than profit and KPIs. It seems to be driven by an interpretation of religion that I can identify with. The kind that drove [mutant 00:00:36] and [likeness 00:00:37] to outdo each other in piety.

By funneling all that was possible, with such limited power of geometrical tricks, Gaudi was pushing the envelope of the realm of the possible. Having seen first hand the effect, the effort it takes to get parts of that building built, it's incredible that so much of it's done. It really is meta-design. The invisible hand of Gaudi defining what can and can't be done, then broadly designing the result. Designing a system, then exercising the system to search for an acceptable result. It all requires an enormous force of will. To plan that far in advance, more than a hundred years, needs a subject matter that barely changes. This church has taken five percent of the whole of Christianity's lifespan to build. The Catholic Church is incredibly resistant to change, so I'd imagine that in another couple of five percents it'll still be fine.

item.title: latop health spa

item.title: Going to NY
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Iâ€™m officially going to New York at the end of the month now for the smart geometry workshop and conference thingy.

That means that apart from having to collect order for about a million ipods and things like that, Iâ€™m actually going to have to work on my proposed plan a bit too!

Itâ€™s ultimate aim is to produce a suite of site analysis tools that you can apply to a site model.

Iâ€™d like to do something like using the US military spy drones or the way they did the â€˜driverâ€™ computer game (like this or this or this) that can scan an area of city and then do loads of test on it using agent models and environmental models and that sort of thing. Then you can start designing with loads of information about the site.

Iâ€™m not planning to make any new methods, just implement other ones in GC and see if I can make anything work.

The other thing Iâ€™m planning on doing is to try and collect the useful stuff that other people are doing and get it all put together on the GCuser website in the toybox so that there is a foundation of gct files and handy scripts for people to build on, bit for learning and making new stuff.

item.title: life changing decision
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I've been thinking a lot recently about what I really want to do with my life, and I'm pretty sure that I'm heading in the right direction, but the lures of being a pastry chef, a carpenter, or a tokyo bike courier are still pretty strong.

after a lot of soul searching I've decided to make a life changing move. I've bought an alarm clock. now i can get up in the morning and get something done with my days!

item.title: Amazon addiction
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I've just had a look at the 'items you own' section of my Amazon profile, and it's over 300!

It's like that moment in sex and the city when Cary does the mental arithmetic about her shoes and realises that's why she can't afford a house (shamefully metaphor I know)

If I average my purchases to be £10 (a conservative estimate) then that's £3000 spent over the last 4 years on Amazon. I think that's enough to get a place at a Betty Ford clinic!

item.title: growing up
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: i'm feeling quite grown up, i've just go myself my second piece of legal commercial software (third if you include windows) so now i have legit copies of Generative Components and of Ecotect, one day i might have lots of legal commercial software, but i might go open source for a few things like office. it's quite a funny feeling after all these years of only having cracked software, but i think that cracked software is still very important. without it i would never have go to the position where i could justify the buying some real software. i really think that companies that charge for student copies of software are shooting themselves in the foot by preventing students getting hooked and thereby making a market once they have graduated.

item.title: In Gear
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: I've decided to stop being so precious about this blog and to just start pouring out my thoughts onto it. There will be posts about my ideas for a collaborative, online, 3d, design system, my dinners, stuff I'm doing, how my thesis is progressing what coffee I'm drinking loads of other stuff and a few links to websites and the like. At the moment I'm trying to drag myself out of a big mental hole caused by a few things, but mainly the fact that since I got my scooter I've been doing absolutely zero exercise. I went for a run on Tuesday and was super wired for hours afterwards, so I'm going to make a concious effort to do as much exercise as I can. I'm going climbing outdoors for the first time since i got back from italy (so that's about six years ago!) so i'm pretty excited. google maps seems to want me to take a bit of a funny route though! Maybe it's an easter egg. I'll try and post some pictures of the goings on on Sunday when i get back.

item.title: Stretch-Hummer Vs Vespa
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: On Saturday morning I got up early and rode down to Weymouth on my Vespa, and apart from the excitement of riding through Islington listening to Love Shack (the strange archaeological effect of having an mp3 collection that has only ever grown over the last 7 years combined with the way that my system randomly loads my player), and the 80mph touring cars extravaganza that is driving through the new forest, it was surprisingly uneventful. One point that stuck in my mind though was being in the middle lane (at about 80) and seeing a black shadow approaching very fast in my wing mirror. as it got closer it turned out to be a hummer, and as it passed me, and passed me, and passed me a load of people (maybe 15-20) looked out of it at me like they were pressing their face up against a fish tank. My initial reaction was of typical treehugger, aloof disgust as the extravagance of it all, but then it struck me that maybe I was being wasteful. A hummer H3 gets a fairly pitiful 14mpg, so a stretch hummer must get about half that, and on the motorway I get about 60mpg (I'm not the most economical driver), but if you work out the MPG/person... stretch hummer -- 100mi@7mpg 14.3/15= 0.95 Vespa GTS -- 100mi@60mpg 1.67/1= 1.67 (gallons per 100miles per person) It turns out that I'm the one with the uneconomical ride. (all that unladen stuff/town driving/embodied energy stuff aside) all hail mass transport eh! I eventually got the last laugh though, because after about 5 miles of playing cat and mouse with it, it had to pull off to get fuel.

item.title: Portland climbing
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: having not climbed out doors for about six years, i was a little apprehensive about this trip to Portland, everyone else has been climbing indoors at least once a week over the winter and tales of grades far harder than I can even dream of have been filtering down to me. the weather was awesome, (i've been saying awesome a lot in the last couple of days) and having only ever climbed granite and sand stone I was amazed at just how grippy the rock was, that certainly adds a lot to your confidence. there were definitely times on some of the dodgy walk-ins that we did where i would have wanted to be roped in! carting around all that gear and walking down steep hills is no fun at all. we stuck mainly to easy stuff, (grade 4) but i did have a crack at leading a climb called "ben" which was a grade 5, and had a fairly ominous write up in the book. I ended up getting to the top without any resting on the rope or falls, which i was well pleased about. On turning around on the top ledge i was rewarded with an awesome (that's where it came from) view of the whole south coast and bright blue sea. I think it must have been adrenaline enhanced, because it didn't look anything like as good from the cliff path above. the end of the first day provided the only chance for avoiding the "does my bum look big in this" climbing shots as we found an arete which the start was way below the rest area, so the photos were from above. the sun was setting behind us as we climbed and it was just so photogenic. it's a shame that the pics make the climb look so easy! the big battles of the weekend were definitely fought in the head, there isn't the comfort zone of the coloured holds telling you where to go next, and falling off can hurt a bit more than your ego, so I'm sure when the mental battles are won I'll be back at the bottom of the pile. more photos after the fold... when they appear

CATEGORY GLOBAL HECTARES

that doesn't fill me with optimism! this is supposed to be the best carbon footprinty thingy around, and although I'm well below the national average, I'm still almost double the goal of 1.8, thank goodness there are poor people in third world counties that don't use their full quota! if you want to try it, it's here

item.title: So boy, what does Architecture mean to you?
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I wrote this in May, but I withdrew it following the advice of a very good friend that it wasn't very well written, which almost certainly translates to "not very well thought out"! Maybe this version is a little better."
This will almost certainly upset a lot of people. It ties in with the thinking that leads me to some of my (slightly rushed) comments here about architects' pay, and about my general feeling about our collective view of our profession and our professional identity.
I've often heard people telling tales of being asked by a seasoned practitioner "so what does architecture mean to you", on their first day in an office. The usual answer is something like Grasshopper gives at the beginning of kung fu, either something naive or something lifted from a book without too much thought because it sounds good. I've been thinking about this question for a long time because none of the answers I've ever heard were particularly satisfactory. Nothing was simple enough to be comprehensible, nor complete enough to be satisfactory; which has lead me to having a crack at defining what it means to me. If you were to ask people what was in this photo, just general people who were walking past, you'd probably get a number of different responses, but I bet you that the top five would have: Sydney, buildings, architecture and skyline amongst it somewhere. If we were to try the same test on the same bunch of general punters then you might get blood, bear, children, medicine, but you almost certainly wouldn't get industrial design or product design. This thought experiment leads me to one of the emerging themes in my moaning about the world; failure of definitions. (I've got a few more posts in the pipeline about that, but it relies on my motivation...) Architecture is both a noun and a verb, and whilst I'm happy with the general public using it both ways, I feel that as a body of professionals we ought to be specific in how we apply it. This is my attempt to be specific. In my formulation of a rough meaning, the skyline shot above is composed of buildings. There are just too many different disciplines involved in the creation of any building much bigger than a garden shed to call it architecture. Doing so indicates a horrific level of arrogance and disrespect for non-architect contributors to the project. It would seem odd to refer to the skyline as a photo of structural engineering, town planning, politics, concrete mixing or contract writing. Yet they are all constituent parts of the huge team that was responsible for that skyline coming into existence. So why should architecture be privileged above all others? This is a question that I don't feel I'm in a position to answer, there is too much history, and I'm still too young to make any sort of attempt that won't just come across as naïve. I think that architecture is a process; a verb. I don't think that too many people would disagree that when someone who self-identifies as 'an architect' goes to work, they do things that they would identify as 'architecture'. I see architecture (verb) to be an organisational role; the task of martialling and synthesising large quantities of information to resolve (often conflicting) constraints. The resolution of those constraints is the product of the process of architecture. The debate about protection of function and the less onerous, but just as hotly contested one on protection of title has often poked an angry stick at 'software architects' as being some sort of joke profession, stealing the title architect as a way to make them sound sexier or more respectable. What they do is conceptually very closely aligned with the role that I think that architects do. They also need resolve complex networks of interdependent constraints and, like (building) architects, their product is a design that is then brought to the end user by a proxy; the software engineer (or in the built environment, the builder). I think that this is a fairly simple concept, and I hope it won't result in my excommunication from too many circles. So to summarise:
  • Architecture is a verb, not a noun.
  • There is no such thing as a piece of architecture, simply a product that is the outcome of a process that architecture was performed during its inception.
  • As architecture is a process, its bounds are not limited to the built environment. Any area that the application of these skills would be beneficial could just as validly use the process.
This seems pretty simple to me, but it has some implications for the protection of name argument that I don't really want to get into, but to put them to bed before they get out of control, I think that there needs to be more made of affiliation to a professional body rather than reliance on an international word to describe why someone ought to hire you or someone of your tribe, and not anyone from different tribe, or heaven forbid a member of no tribe at all.

item.title: Elegant pattern trick
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
While Sophie was here over Christmas she wanted to learn a bit of programming. We did quite a few nerdy things, but I think that this was the nerdiest. We got through all the usual stuff about loops and conditional statements, but this didn't take long and before I knew what was going on I was explaining in as much detail as I was able the difference between functions and methods, and how inheritance worked for classes, what abstract classes were etc. Anyway, the point of this is that we worked out a pattern drawing method for 3d grids of things. In this case they are little snowflakey things that are drawn alternately big and small, but it could be anything. The secret is wrapped up in this one little innocuous line: 
sizeController = ( (j%2) + (k%2) + (m%2) ) %2
Which needs a bit of unpacking before it makes sense. The three loop controllers (m, j, k) are positive integers which can all be either odd or even numbers. There are a number of different combinations of odd and even throughout the grid, so if we make a little table of them:
000 001 010 011 100 101 111
m even even even even odd odd odd
j even even odd odd even even odd
k even odd even odd even odd odd
That doesn't really make much sense, but if we test the oddness of the numbers using the %2 method then we get:
000 001 010 011 100 101 111
m 0 0 0 0 1 1 1
j 0 0 1 1 0 0 1
k 0 1 0 1 0 1 1
Which is still a bit obscure, but there is more we can do with it because it is numbers rather than words. While we're deep in this confusion, We've only used the addresses with 0s and 1s in them because it is easier for me to count up in binary to 6 rather than to work out the relative positions - you could just have easily picked a place in the middle of the grid and taken the offsets from there. So this is the trick, the bit where it gets really elegant. You add up the vertical columns and then that the %2 of those numbers:
000 001 010 011 100 101 111
m 0 0 0 0 1 1 1
j 0 0 1 1 0 0 1
k 0 1 0 1 0 1 1
? 0 1 1 2 1 2 3
%2 0 1 1 0 1 0 1
small big big small big small big
and all of that packs down into that one line! So here's the minimal code, and after the fold is the code that draws the snowflakes in SketchUp 
for m in (0..4)
  for j in (0..4)
    for k in (0..4)

      isOdd = ( (j%2) + (k%2) + (m%2) ) %2
      if isOdd == 0
        #do some stuff because it's even
        puts 'big'
      else
        #do some stuff because it's odd
        puts 'small'
      end

    end # for k (controlling y_axis)
  end # for j (controlling x_axis)
end # for m (controlling z_axis)
and here's the snowflake making code. 
mod = Sketchup.active_model
ent = mod.entities
sel = mod.selection

radius = 10
numPoints = 35
spacingMultiplier = 4
spacing = radius * spacingMultiplier
mod = Sketchup.active_model
ent = mod.entities
sel = mod.selection

radius = 10
numPoints = 35
spacingMultiplier = 4
spacing = radius * spacingMultiplier

for m in (0..4)
  for j in (0..4)
    for k in (0..4)

      sizeController = ( (j%2) + (k%2) + (m%2) ) %2
      radius = radius * sizeController + 10

      origin_x = j * spacing
      origin_y = k * spacing
      origin_z = m * spacing

      p1 = [origin_x , origin_y , origin_z]

      for i in (0..numPoints)
        angleInDegrees = i.degrees*10
        p2x_val = radius * Math.sin(angleInDegrees)
        p2y_val = radius * Math.cos(angleInDegrees)
        p2 = [0+p1[0], p2x_val+p1[1] , p2y_val+p1[2]]
        ent.add_line(p1,p2)
      end

      for i in (0..numPoints)
        angleInDegrees = i.degrees*10
        p2x_val = radius * Math.sin(angleInDegrees)
        p2y_val = radius * Math.cos(angleInDegrees)
        p2 = [p2x_val+p1[0] , p2y_val+p1[1] , 0+p1[2]]
        ent.add_line(p1,p2)
      end

      for i in (0..numPoints)
        angleInDegrees = i.degrees*10
        p2x_val = radius * Math.sin(angleInDegrees)
        p2y_val = radius * Math.cos(angleInDegrees)
        p2 = [p2y_val+p1[0] , 0+p1[1] , p2x_val+p1[2]]
        ent.add_line(p1,p2)
      end 

    end # for k (controlling y_axis)
  end # for j (controlling x_axis)
end # for m (controlling z_axis)
This could be a bit more tightly written, but for a first lesson in programming it's some very impressive stuff!

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: We all seem to be comfortable with the ideas of knowledge capital and status, but why did I write about them? No prizes for guessing; I think they are related! Some of the status games we play are about impressing people outside our clan. As Jan points out we like symbols of our status so that we don't need to fight and beat our chests in meetings. We have subtle indicators like better clothes[1. or sometimes worse clothes, e.g. Zukaberg's hoodie.], the deference of others, titles on business cards. Of course all this matters much less once everyone is talking and the brain-battle is on, but it helps set the stage. Most of the status games we play are to jockey for position within the clan. BVN is bigger than Dunbar's magic number (100-150 people) for group coherence. Sydney alone is around 160! That means that there is a lot of status play needed to keep your importance[1. Sydney might even break into two tribes! E.g. North doesn't talk to South. ]. We have traditionally had a strongly hierarchical, but flatish structure[1. With senior versions of associates and practice directors (and arguably principals, all equal, but some more equal than others) we are getting less flat.]. That means that it's obvious who holds power. This also means that it seems obvious who one ought to try to be like to get oneself more power eventually. I believe that this model of imitation and succession is what happens. I'd also like to argue that it is dangerous. This is going to be hard and I'm going to get on the wrong side of people, so I'd love if this generated some meaty comments below. We all try to achieve status and, through that status, career advancement. One easy way to do this is to try to be like high status people who are on our projected path. The problem with this is that we are terrible at aiming that path! [diagram of paths missing] Most of the choices we make to ape high status people are unconscious. The thing that we forget[1. "Forget" is the wrong word because it implies that we could chose not to.] about when we aim for where people are is that it took time to get there[1. This is classic artillery stuff, aim for where they are going to be.]! By the time you catch up, they'll be old and irrelevant, and you'll be middle aged and irrelevant. You'll never pass through the status apex that they did. To put it more bluntly: don't try to be like them, they are the past. For you to succeed you need to identify what a person of similar status will be like in the future and be like them! Why have I gone on this important-person-bashing rant? I think that it's important when we're thinking about how to act today. High status people define high status activities just by doing them. The important thing to notice about that is the inverse. They define low status activities by not doing them. We assume that the things that those people do are important and the things they don't do are worthless, and we work out our own priorities based on that. This only works fine if there is no progress[1. I know that progress is a difficult concept. If we assume that I'm using in the lazy way, and not assuming any kind of teleological destiny then we'll all be OK!] and we know that's not the world we live in. Enough of this abstract stuff, lets be specific. The reason I talk about knowledge capital is that creating it doesn't translate into status. If someone brings in a bucket load of cash then they are going to get a status bump. If another person creates a load of really valuable knowledge capital nobody really cares. (As a quick reminder, knowledge capital is when you get knowledge out of your head and into a format that other's can use to make them better at things.) Because high status people at BVN make bucket loads of cash, that activity is high status. That means that people aspire to do the same thing. Creating knowledge capital is almost never done by high status people at BVN, that means that it is very obviously low status[1. With the notable exception of Craig's excellent piece on corrosion. I create a lot of knowledge capital, but I don't feel as if it gets me any advancement on the 'normal' path--perhaps further down the wierdo path?]. That leads to a social situation where even if people will privately agree that they should be doing something to share knowledge, when it comes to the crunch it is never prioritised highly[1. One of the things that's been discussed a lot recently is the idea that "too busy" to do something is a bullshit concept. What it really means is that that person doesn't prioritise that activity highly enough to do it. This isn't a slur on that person, it's just a lingustic pitfall. I might write more about it soon.] enough to happen. This creates an impasse. Nobody creates knowledge capital, nobody want to be the first as it's a low status activity, so it doesn't happen. A status game is preventing BVN from becoming far more effective. That means that a status game is keeping your salary down. Concern about status is harming your lifestyle, your kids, the whole industry. That's something to think about.

item.title: Analysing PredictionBook
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
A couple of years ago[1. when I first wrote this line it said "a couple of months ago. Then I sat on it for ages."] I did the data science course at General Assembly in Sydney. As a part of the requirements of that course I needed to do a 'project' to give the abstract skills in machine learning some realistic grounding. Since I already had an academic interest in Prediction book I thought that it'd be great to ask them if they'd give me some data to have a look at. Much to my surprise Wesley from Trike (the people who make Prediction Book) got straight back to me with some sanitised[1. Prediction book gave me a sanitised version of their data (no names, email addresses, prediction text or anything that could be used to make the data personal) as an sql database (7.7mb)] data. In the last two years there's been a fair bit of code rot, so this is only the first half of the work--descriptive analytics mainly. There is more to come, that bit is more fancy, but actually less useful. There is also a full listing of the code in this repo. The work is done in iPython notebook (now Jupyter) with Pandas.

Plan/Hypothesis

This is probably the biggest thing I learned from the whole process: You should go into this kind of thing with a plan! My hypothesis was that "There's lots of data, on a topic that I'm interested in, so there must me something to be learned". It turns out that this makes it hard for a bunch of reasons.
  1. I didn't know what to look for. If I'd had a falsifiable hypothesis then I'd be able to develop tests that would support or disprove it. As it was I was just endlessly describing the data until I found something that was interesting enough to find out about.
  2. Not having a hypothesis also makes it difficult to decide if you are 'done' or not.
  3. Having a plan or a hypothesis gives you a domain of machine learning to get your teeth into. This is a bit arbitrary in real life, but as this is essentially a synthetic situation that needs me to demonstrate some ability with a skillset it would have been a lot easier to say "make a recommendation system" because then I could learn all about recommendation systems and try to make one that worked with my data.
As it turned out, my plan was just to trawl around looking for something interesting. What I should have done was spent some time interviewing PB users[1. maybe even interviewing myself] about what they wanted out of the site. That would have given me a much tighter series of questions.

What is Prediction Book?

[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="652"] A screenshot of my PredictionBook page. Showing that I'm actually underconfident at the top end of things, and over confident around 50%.[/caption] PredictionBook is a website that allows people to record their predictions and their confidence in those predictions, then track that over time. I first came across it when I was writing about overconfidence, and I've been using it intermittently ever since. The site allows users to make public and private predictions. It'll then remind them to judge them once they should be known. Users can also weigh in on other people's predictions with confidence assessments, like a free prediction market. This means that users can make judgements over a variety of time scales and confidence intervals.

Users

There are 22235 rows in the users table, they've made 21913 predictions and 10798 judgements[as of 18/12/2013 when the database was exported.]. However of those 22k users, only 900 have made and judged a prediction which is the key thing for assessing their calibration. There's a pretty strong skew to those people too. To get any kind reliable calibration assessment you need about 50 answered questions, and it doesn't start to settle down until about 100 judgements. That meant that there were about 100 strong contenders for analysis. I can figure out the confidence distribution for each person. Here's an example of person #500. Consistently slightly overconfident, except on things that they are very pessimistic about. The circles show how many judgements they'd made at each confidence level. They are hard to differentiate, so the lower graph is same info but easier to read.

Are people who use prediction more better calibrated?

This raises all kinds of questions about the arrow of causation. Are well calibrated people likely to come to PredictionBook to start with? Did they get better over time? Did they leave because they were bad at guessing their accuracy? The data say that people who make more predictions seem to be better calibrated. There's even a weak trend that they get better as they make more prediction. This graph is the Summed Square Error (SSE) of the predictions. Because it's squared it punishes big errors much more than small ones, so to have a small number is a good thing. The people who are really prolific also have really small SSE, so that looks good! I was interested to see if they were over or underconfident, and it seems that most of the best predictors are slightly underconfident overall. There seems to be a very weak trend to slightly under confident, but that is unintuitive and might just be noise.

Do people get better calibrated over time?

A pretty obvious question is do people get 'better' (i.e. seem to have better calibration) over time? in fact, there's an issue for this on the repo: Find out if PB makes people better calibrated over time It seems like using prediction book should lead to improvements, lets see: The way I'm showing this is by going a SSSE for a window of time, and then moving the window. The bigger the window the more damping there is going to be. The graph above shows the results for user 500 over their whole PB lifespan moving 2 weeks at a time. The difference between the lines is the window size. I think there is some kind of comparison error here as the red lines don't seem to be a more damped version of the yellow ones, but as long as I keep the window size the same for all the users it ought to be comparable. Rather disappointingly, it seems that the questions is unanswered. There seems to be some kind of trend towards the 0 line as we travel right, but not in enough people to let me believe that it is more than me just seeing what I want to see. This one needs a bit more attention.

Recommendations to Prediction Book

Having gone through this, PB are doing a pretty good job! Everything I will recommend is really a feature request, it is also based on a lot of speculation and not real user discussion. The first thing that stands out is the number of passive users, people who have never made a prediction or only make judgements on other people's predictions. [graph here of user activity, label the point when it goes under 100 predictions, and when it goes under 1] Decision making calibration is a pretty niche area, so I would imagine that most people who sign up have a vague idea what they are getting into. However the incredibly high proportion of people who fail to make even a single prediction indicates that there is something getting in the way of them getting their calibration adequately quantified. My guess is that it's blank slate terror. There are social rules amongst PB users about what to leave public, what to make private etc. and as a new user the first prediction is hard to make. I'd suggest a longer sign up process that takes people through a series of curated questions to get a base level of calibration for new users. Ok Cupid does this to great effect, but there might be challenges in getting questions that can be judged repeatedly without becoming obsolete. To get a useful calibration graph I've worked out that you need roughly 100 predictions to be judged. (This is just based on guessing and scribbling, not on data.) Getting people started on a set of questions would put them on track for getting to a useful graph. Using PB has an incredibly big investment of time and attention before the user sees any pay back; anything that can be done to get new users to that point is going to make it more accessible. The calibration graph is great for intermediate users who have made their first 100 predictions and are happy knowing that if they say 50/50 then really they mean that there's a 60% chance that it won't happen. Users who have a longer history and more predictions would benefit from knowing if their calibration on 60% will happen is better than their calibration on 40% won't. If users had enough data points they might even like to see (using something like crossfilter) whether their long term (far mode) predictions are better than their short term ones, or if they are better calibrated in the morning.

and?

One meta thing that came out of this is that you should make presentations and summaries of data while you still have it all loaded into your brain! It's taken a lot of effort to understand what the past me was doing when he wrote this code.

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: I'm currently writing a piece about Christopher Alexander's book Notes on the synthesis of form. I've read part one about 4 times now and it's either warpign my brain, or he had a good point to start with because I'm starting to agree with a lot of what he says (part 2 is a differnt story) I did a little presentation about it a while ago, it's here if you want to have a look. I'll even post the essay when it's done! Now don't you feel lucky

item.title: indoor greenhouse
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: I've been talkingÂ  about this to anyone who will listen for ages now! I have an enormous bay window in my living room that gets blasted by the sun between about 5am and 1pm everyday. it seems a shame to waste all that energy on the two ropey plants that came with my flat, so I've got myself a grow bag and some seeds and I'm growing tomatoes. I'll keep a tomato update going over the summer as they progress. I think there isÂ  probably room for another 2 bags in there, so I'll grow a few mint plants, in one, but I'm still searching for ideas for the other one. ThisÂ  takes the idea of local food to a whole new level!

item.title: Burgernomics
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
i find this idea fascinating, it's the modern equivalent of asking how many loaves of bread something cost

Big Mac Index

Burgernomics is based on the theory of purchasing-power parity, the notion that a dollar should buy the same amount in all countries. Thus in the long run, the exchange rate between two countries should move towards the rate that equalises the prices of an identical basket of goods and services in each country. Our "basket" is a McDonald's Big Mac, which is produced in about 120 countries. The Big Mac PPP is the exchange rate that would mean hamburgers cost the same in America as abroad. Comparing actual exchange rates with PPPs indicates whether a currency is under- or overvalued.
via the economist while i was looking for a picture, i discovered that in different countries, Big macs have different recipes and calorific values. A US 'mac has 540 calories and an Australian one has 48. (wikipedia)

Forgive me father for I have sinned - I've been really slack keeping this thing up to date, but as I have a bit more time at the moment, I will try and be a bit better. (not being in the slightest bit religious, I have no idea what comes next)

Here's a picture of my tomato, it's a singular tomato, but there are lots of flowers coming, so hopefully he won't be lonely for too much longer. The plants are really enjoying being tied up (kinky plants) and are now about 1.5 m tall. They provide ample screening for me to indulge in one of my favourite pastimes, namely strolling about my flat in just my pants.

I'm off to see the Anthony Gormley exhibition in a bit, so I'll stick some photos up when I get the chance.

item.title: code tree
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: I know I bang on about this collaborative working stuff all the time, but code tree is a great example of some people who are into the same sort of stuff just getting on with it and doing something. There is something quite 80's hacker about the way that they are all just throwing down and trying to better the last guy, but there is no secrecy and bitchy one-upmanship, all the code is shared, so it's a great place to learn some stuff. check it out, there is some beautiful work up there already, and it's only been going about 1 minute!

item.content:encoded: Go Kawakita is doing a masters at Brookes as a part of their MSc in Energy Efficient and Sustainable Building program, and as his thesis subject is so similar to mine, I'm tutoring him a bit. He's going to be prolifically blogging about what he's doing on his blog, ETSDL. Keep coming back, as it should be interesting! (Hopefully he'll make it look a bit nicer soon though!)

I've got to put together a huge amount of info by Monday to send off to them with a super fast courier to Melbourne.

item.title: I'm not ignoring you!
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: If anyone tries calling me in the next few days, there is only a very tiny chance that I will pick up. I've cracked the screen on my phone, and as it was in silent mode when it happened, the only way I can tell if someone is calling is by the screen flashing. It's a pretty good indicator of my current mental state that when i first saw it, I thought that I'd been sent a really beautiful picture of a leaf.
