Check out the first thing we've opened, our style guide. Keep an eye out for more! We'd love for people to fork this, make contributions etc. The repo is here. It's by no means perfect, we're taking a launch early and often approach. There will be modifications and new sections made quite frequently for the foreseeable future.

item.title: Drones make us care about what's happening on the roof
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Suddenly it is normal to get site photography from a drone at the start of an architectural project. As buildings get designed they get montaged into site photos. Traditionally those photos were from ground level. Now that has changed, the the designer is continually reminded of the roof[1. It also means that the building will be photographed from above much more often during its life. Especially as more people get drones and those drones get more capable.].
There's always been a lot of interest in facades, especially since computers made getting fancy accessible to the masses. Since roofs stopped being highly visible (think cathedrals etc.) the roof has been a bit of an afterthought. There have been some notable exceptions, but usually it's just a place to shove unwanted air-con equipment. This post isn't supposed to be anything more than a quick observation. Keep an eye out for people paying more attention to roofscapes, I bet it's because of drone photography. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Facebook's roof garden[/caption]

item.title: Grind size analysis app
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Another app idea that I'm never going to make so someone else can have it. Grid size is really hard to get right for home coffee nerds. If you've got a 250g bag of something expensive, you can't run half of it through the grinder to get the grind right. This is an especially big problem if you are running different brew techniques[1. We've got one of almost everything in our house except turkish and espresso.]. The factors everyone cares about are particle size and consistency. How big are the chunks, and how much do those sizes vary? Modern smartphone cameras are amazingly high resolution. This photo is a crop out of the middle of a picture from my Nexus 6p on 5mm squared paper. At my screen resolution each square is about 25mm, so that's plenty of magnification. The question is:
Can modern smartphone cameras + computer vision + some graph paper[1. Graph paper for context, maybe you could use some other context thing, like a Nickel or a ruler.] measure particle size usefully well?
Here's an enlarged square, bigger than 100%: I have no idea if there is enough contrast in the images for the CV algorithm to see grain boundaries. Maybe that's not even required, perhaps you can just do blob detection on the smallest particles? Seems like a pretty straight middle section, and maybe you could just discard anything really big as likely to be a clump? Anyway, let me know if you are a CV genius and you make this app, I'd use it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An idea for a Grind size analysis app?

item.title: Connecting Rescue time to Habitica: How to reward yourself for doing useful things without using up all your brain power
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I like Habitica a lot. I find that it's good at directing my attention and motivating me to do things that are aligned with my goals[1. i.e. it gets me to do things that the good version of myself thinks are useful. The things that--given some time to think about it and plan--I would want to be doing.]. I also use Rescue Time, it's job is to tell me what I really do with my life. It stops me lying to myself about what my days look like. I've tried manually inputting habits in the past. If I worked well for an hour I'd give myself a point. But if I was really working I'd forget to put in the point, and if I was actually just barely working I'd remember. Generally reinforcing the wrong habit.

Enough intro, onto the nerd stuff!

IFTTT and Zapier both have a connection to Rescue Time. They both have a way of emitting cURL commands too. IFTTT through the Maker channel and Zapier through webhooks. That means that if I do something in real life then I can be rewarded or punished in Habitica land.

How do I unlock this sorcery?

I'll do this for Zapier because it's easier to test, but the same holds for IFTTT[1. Now that I've got it working, I'd actually make it in IFTTT, Zapier is pretty crippled unless you pay real money for it.]. You can also swap out Rescue Time for any other trigger too. So if you want to get a reward when you go into the gym's geofence then you can. Obvious stuff: get a Zapier/IFTTT and Habitica account. You are going to need to get your Habitica API details; they live here. (The User ID and API Token.) Once you've got your ingredients all ready then you can get going! Pick something you want to be rewarded (or punished) for. Something that Rescue Time tracks. Then make a custom subcategory for it.[1. You can put other activities into that category if you want them measured on the same timer if you like.] Then set a new goal. You're all done in Rescue Time now. Go to Zapier and make a new Zap. Set it to be triggered by your goal. Now for the voodoo part. There is a good page on the Habitica wiki that explains everything I'm about to say. I was having a severe stupid when I was reading it, so in case my words are useful, then here they are. The call to the API is a POST like this: https://habitica.com/api/v2/user/tasks/read20minutes/up The bit in red is the name of the habit. (Multiple triggers can aim at the same habit.) The green bit is either up or down depending on where you want your score to go. That goes into the URL field. This is the part that I spent all the time on. Your authentication details go in the header, not the body. That's right at the end of section 5. Make 2 new key, value pairs with your details. That's it! don't change anything else and you'll be just fine. Test it in step 6, name it in step 7 and away you go! When you test it you should see a new Habitica habit show up. Then if you test it again it'll go green. (Unless you're a punisher and you picked down!) And that is that. If you have any clever ideas for other things to join up then let me know. I'm a total sucker for this stuff.

item.title: Deep work, and my first steps
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I just read Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World by Cal Newport. It sits well with a lot of the stuff I've been reading recently as a member of the commons at BVN. His main argument is that being able to do deep work gives you a huge competitive advantage. By deep work he means something that will advance your agenda in life, but also needs your specific skills. So I can send a bunch of emails, or go to a load of meetings, but really I could delegate that. Deep work is the stuff that you are uniquely suited to, and that required your undivided attention. Divided attention results in shallow work. If you are interrupted a lot then it's impossible to get into the flow of what you are doing. (See Maker schedule, manager schedule) This book would be a good bet for most people. I'm trying to implement some things from it as my attention is notoriously fleeting. The irony of reading a book about deep work and then flitting across to Facebook as I got bored didn't escape me.

Things I did

The first thing was to take away my default attention sink. My attention span is somewhere between 2-5 minutes if I'm not into something. I'll feel a strong urge to look at something mindless, to the point where sometimes I'll get bored of looking at Facebook and try to open Facebook to alleviate the dullness! I took Facebook and Instagram off my phone[1. Where I do most of my reading now that I have a massive screen 6p]. I've been surprised by how fast I've acclimatised. I've left Messenger so that I'm still contactable, but I've found that the notifications are very distracting, which brings me to my next thing. To get myself to commit to solid periods of deep work I've started using Clockwork Tomato. It's a Pomodoro timer that sets me up to do 25 minutes of work followed by a 5 minute break[1. it's slightly more complicated, but that's the gist. Here's a bit more detail]. The nice feature that this particular timer has is Tasker integration. It's like an IFTTT, but less friendly and more hackable. One of the things it can do is turn off the WiFi on my phone. I don't have a SIM card in my phone[1. I just don't see the point, but that's a different story], so turning off the WiFi makes me uncontactable. What this means is that I'm committing to 25 minutes of focussed work, without anyone to distract me. That's not a super long time, but for someone with an attention span like mine it's an eternity and is great deep work training. One of the nice side effect is that it is a great reward when Tasker turns the wifi back on and I get a flood of notifications that I can faff with for 5 minutes before it cuts me off again[1. This post, It's time for notifications to get smart, from the Intercom blog has some good ideas about how to make this notification thing work for you rather than against.]. I'm considering a few more things like this, but I haven't got around to them yet. I might do something that turns the WiFi off in the house when I should be sleeping, and that uses Rescuetime to block certain websites e.g. blocking work websites outside work times. If you've got any ideas, then let me know!

Quotes from the book

I highlight when I read a kindle book[1. which is pretty much the only way I read books at the moment.]. There is a handy website that collects them all up; here's what I highlighted: Here's Cal's method, in his own words:
I build my days around a core of carefully chosen deep work, with the shallow activities I absolutely cannot avoid batched into smaller bursts at the peripheries of my schedule. Three to four hours a day, five days a week, of uninterrupted and carefully directed concentration, it turns out, can produce a lot of valuable output.
He makes a good point about how the mid-term future will most likely be a blended teams scenario. "The key question will be: are you good at working with intelligent machines or not?" His point is that deep work is rarely automatable, so safeguards your livelihood from the robots! E.g.:
when money is made through the combination of capital investment and labor, the rewards are returned, roughly speaking, proportional to the input. As digital technology reduces the need for labor in many industries, the proportion of the rewards returned to those who own the intelligent machines is growing.
This is his equation and I think it makes sense:
High-Quality Work Produced = (Time Spent) × (Intensity of Focus)
I like how if you put a low value in for Intensity of Focus you'll get a low amount of value! Richard Feynman (total hero of virtually everyone I know) said this:
To do real good physics work, you do need absolute solid lengths of time … it needs a lot of concentration … if you have a job administrating anything, you don't have the time. So I have invented another myth for myself: that I'm irresponsible. I'm actively irresponsible. I tell everyone I don't do anything. If anyone asks me to be on a committee for admissions, "no," I tell them: I'm irresponsible.
Turns out that I've been cultivating an air of irresponsibility too! Mr Flow himself:
Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi… explicitly identifies this advantage when he emphasizes the advantage of cultivating "concentration so intense that there is no attention left over to think about anything irrelevant, or to worry about problems.")
This is about the difference between work and craft.
Beautiful code is short and concise, so if you were to give that code to another programmer they would say, "oh, that's well written code." It's much like as if you were writing a poem.
Within the overall structure of a project there is always room for individuality and craftsmanship … One hundred years from now, our engineering may seem as archaic as the techniques used by medieval cathedral builders seem to today's civil engineers, while our craftsmanship will still be honored.
This is a useful mantra:
When you work, work hard. When you're done, be done.
This is something that I see afflicting so many people, including me. The quality of rest you get between periods of work directly influences the intensity that you are able to work when you are working. If you let the work bleed into the rest then the rest will bleed into the work and diminish the quality of both! In Cal's words: attack the task with every free neuron until it gives way under your unwavering barrage of concentration. Basecamp gives their people 4 day weeks in the summer, rather than doing 80% of the work they still did 100% (or more) of the work in 80% of the time:
the reduction in the 37signals work week disproportionately eliminated shallow as compared to deep work, and because the latter was left largely untouched, the important stuff continued to get done.
They liked this, so:
our theory is that we'll see better results when people have a long stretch of uninterrupted time." To test this theory, 37signals implemented something radical: The company gave its employees the entire month of June off to work deeply on their own projects.
Those projects have produced some of the features that generate a bunch of Basecamp's income! Without them they'd be grinding along with their old feature set.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Deep work, and my first steps

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
How and Why to Slack
I just checked my email. Oh gawd I didn't realise everyone spams everyone!

Quote from Alex Lee upon opening his BVN inbox for the first time.

That's probably going to embarrass Alex a bit, but I think it helps to have a fresh set of eyes on things. Our inboxes are supposed to be for important things. Imagine yourself in a Madmen scene. You are an Important Person. Twice a day you go through your actual-paper inbox. Wouldn't you be sad if it was full of low value junk? [caption id="attachment_2648" align="alignright" width="359"] This is not anyone's fault. There isn't currently a place for us to have this kind of communication that doesn't pollute the inbox.[/caption] So many emails that are valuable to someone, but not everyone, start with "Sorry for the group email but...". We don't have an effective way to keep that kind of communication out of the inbox. The reason we don't have an effective way to do this is not enough eyeballs! Email inboxes are the only place that we know that lots of people look, so that's where we direct our questions. What if that wasn't true? How could we do that? Well, we have Slack. We started using slack for the Commons, but there's no reason not to extend it even further. Chris has written about slack before and lots of people have signed up. What would be really great is if everyone signed up, then we'd have the network effect we need to take the pressure off email. Slack has channels, they are a bit like radio stations. You subscribe to the channels that you want to. So if you are into ESD, there's a channel for that, there's a channel for rosa to announce library things etc. We can make channels for anything. That means that there's a fence around the topic. That keeps the topic focused, it means that you know where to look to get information back again. Most importantly, it allows you to focus on only the things that you care about right now. You can get an app on your phone too, so you can catch up on the latest from the ping pong tournament on the train. We don't have any official rules about how to use it, so lets all evolve those rules together. Also, use a bit of common sense, don't upload DoD documents to it or anything dumb like that. Go, sign up, suggest channels and let's have a joyous new world where we're excellent at communicating!

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
You know what's really annoying? Lots of things actually, but one of them is this: But they have a point! Our graphic standards are totally internal. That means that we know how to use the logo. In explicit detail! There is a lot of work that goes into making a consistent graphic identity. The problem is that nobody who we give the logo to, the people who are making sponsor posters, have any idea about all that work!

The front end

We've solved that problem! From now on you can send people to this address[1. what is the address? Should it be the gh one or should it get it's own? there are .style tlds and bvn.style is available] and they can see all the graphic guidelines and get all the assets they need. That will mean that they have everything they need to use those assets in line with our intent. It also means that you can check the graphic guidelines from your phone or your computer whenever you want. The tropos menu points to that location, and you can save the address as a bookmark in your phone. Having one source of information for everyone (internal and external) means that the information is always current. There's no risk of the info going out of alignment because one version has been updated and the other hasn't.

The back end

The style guide is hosted on GitHub. That means that it's open source. It means that anyone in the world can contribute to the style guide. Clutch the pearls! What horrors are we letting ourselves in for? The way GitHub works is very structured. More so than Wikipedia. Contributions are handled through a pull request. That means that the contributor is requesting that the owner of the content pulls in their changes. That gives us, the owners, total control. The upside is that it also gives anyone the chance to fix typos and little mistakes really easily.

Trickle down benefits

One of my greatest frustrations is that architects seem to spend more time trying to thwart each other than help each other. This is a move to help our peers. If they want to take our style guide and use all or parts of it themselves then that's great. It positions us a leaders. In a tiny way, it also reduces friction at the boundaries between collaborators. If we work with someone who uses the same standards as we do, then things are simpler. We can spend more time doing what we should be doing and less time fixing.

Launch early and often

This is a bit of a war cry of startup culture. The idea is that the only way to find out if people actually want something is to get it in front of them. This means that we can avoid spending time worrying over details that nobody cares about, when we're actually missing something huge that really matters. At BVN we are particularly guilty of launching late and once. This is understandable because buildings are a bit hard to launch early and often[1. but not impossible I'm sure!]. Something on the web is never finished, there is always more to do. If we wait until we're finished we'll never launch, so we're launching today.

How can you help?

If you spot something that needs to be fixed, if you feel like some wording should be changed, anything, then you can help. Submit an issue ticket, or even better a pull request, and we'll sort it out. Details of how to do that are here on Bloomfire.

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
Architects seem to act in a 'us vs them' way to other architects. This is probably the case in lots of other industries, but it's not going to help drive the explosive growth that software-backed industries have seen.
I don't think that it's really an 'us vs them' situation. I prefer to think about it as 'us vs nature'. When there are more of us then it becomes easier to overcome nature.
Open source web technology has changed the way that the world works. Something like 90% of the internet is runs on Linux servers, with OS software. This culture has led to commercial companies like Twitter sharing things like their Bootstrap library. This has meant that it's trivially easy to set up a good looking website and to get your self out on the internet.
This hasn't cost Twitter anything, they were doing it anyway! It <em>has</em> unlocked huge amounts of value for other people. That's just a simple example, there are thousands of others out there.
Nothing like that exists for architecture.
There are a couple of companies out there that are doing open source design work [put in the examples]. I'm a huge fan of the the work that they are doing, but I don't think that the industry is ready for them. There are lower hanging fruit!
Architects compete on a number of dimensions. Mostly it's cost, but we'd prefer to claim that it's design quality. I'd like it to be <em>mostly</em> deign quality. That means that anything that we, as an industry, can do to reduce costs associated with non-design things is a Good Thing.
One of the things that we spend time on is admin. That's a super broad term. It could mean cleaning the office and buying paper clips, or it could mean coordinating documents. YOu can make a claim that it's possible to compete on the ability to get your admin done faster and better than the next person. That's true, but I don't want to be that guy!
That's why at BVN we've decided to start open sourcing some of our assets. It's going to be a slow start, but we're going to identify things that don't really give us a competitive advantage and share them.
Hopefully this will prompt others to do the same. Over time we can make pull requests against each other's assets and make them better. Hopefully we can make common assets out of the best bits.
This uses the web concept of <em>paving the cow paths</em>. That means that standards emerge out of what people are already doing. Whilst I have a lot of respect for standards organisations, they are rarely fast enough to be meaningful. This allows people to adopt what they find useful and ignore what they don't.
We're going to try to open up more of our assets over time. If other practices adopt them then that's great! Hopefully it'll help them. It'll also help us if we ever work with someone who uses the same assets and protocols as it'll reduce friction at the boundary between the two organisations.
Check out the first thing we've opened, our style guide. Keep an eye out for more!

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded: Architects seem to act in a 'us vs them' way to other architects. I'll bet that this is the case in lots of other industries. If we want to see the explosive growth that we see software-backed industries we need to be different. I don't think that it should be an 'us vs them' situation. I prefer to think about it as 'us vs nature'. When there are more of us then it becomes easier to overcome nature. Open source (OS) web technology has changed the way that the world works. Something like 90% of the internet is runs on Linux servers, with OS software. This culture has led to commercial companies like Twitter sharing things like their Bootstrap library. This kind of thing has made it super easy to set up a good looking website and to get yourself out on the internet. This hasn't cost Twitter anything extra, they were doing it anyway! It has unlocked huge amounts of value for other people. That's just a simple example but there are thousands of others out there. Nothing like that exists for architecture. There are a couple of companies out there that are doing open source design work [put in the examples]. I'm a huge fan of the the work that they are doing, but I don't think that the industry is ready for them. There are lower hanging fruit! Architects compete on lots of dimensions. Mostly it's cost, but we'd prefer to claim that it's design quality. I'd like it to be mostly deign quality. Anything that our industry can do to reduce costs from non-design things is a Good Thing. One of the things that we spend time on is admin. That's a super broad term. It could mean cleaning the office and buying paper clips, or it could mean coordinating documents. It's possible to compete on the ability to get your admin done faster and better than the next person. I don't want to be that guy! That's why, at BVN, we've decided to start open sourcing some of our assets. It's going to be a slow start! We're going to identify things that don't really give us a competitive advantage, and share them. Hopefully this will prompt others to do the same. Over time we can make pull requests against each other's assets and make them better. Imagine if we can make common, super-assets out of the best bits. This uses the web concept of paving the cow paths. That means that standards emerge out of what people are already doing. I have a lot of respect for standards organisations but they are rarely fast enough to be meaningful. This allows people to adopt what they find useful and ignore what they don't. We're going to try to open up more of our assets over time. If other practices adopt them then that's great! Hopefully it'll help them. It'll also help us if we ever work with someone who uses the same assets and protocols. Because we'll have a common language it'll reduce friction at the boundary between us. Check out the first thing we've opened, our style guide. Keep an eye out for more!

item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
ReLease ideas

I tried to explain this to a friend recently. I ended up needing to keep rolling back layers, so I'll try and start at the base layer and work up. It might feel a bit abstract, but if you stick with it until the end it should make more sense. (Perhaps a chose-your-own-adventure style would be better?)

The first thing to explain is the way software gets to it's customers. To begin with (in the 70s) a man in a suit would come to your business. (In those days only businesses could afford software.) He'd sell you the idea of the software over a few expensive lunches. Then a bus-load of nerds would come and camp out at your HQ. They'd tailor the software to fit your system. This wasn't easy because each system was different and everyone wanted different things from the software.

Eventually compliers padded the gap between individual systems (hardware) and the software that ran on them. People could make software more generically and sell it to people who--although still highly technical--weren't professional software nerds. (We're in the windows 3 era now, early 90s.)

Not much changed until about 2007 when chrome was first released. By now some software was downloaded and installed instead of coming on a disk, but the process was more or less the same.

There had been a few bits of software that had downloadable patches. They tended to have a warning that a told you that a new version was available and that you were welcome to update your system (if you felt like it)[1. By now windows was doing regular patches that applied when you restarted, and Linux package management was going strong, but that was on the fringes.]. Chrome was the first, really mainstream bit of software that silently updated. That meant that it was only the most tech-savvy who were behind the latest version[1. and therefore vulnerable to things going wrong.] rather than the opposite.

You are probably wondering why this matters in this context. I'll bring this specific idea back again later, but for now the important thing is what underlies this trend; what makes it possible!

We're all old enough to remember when software came in shrink wrapped boxes. A new version would come out once a year or so. This meant that the whole cadence of the producers was geared around producing these massive, monolithic releases. Waterfall planning found a perfect niche here in working out what could and couldn't be fitted into 'the next release'. Usually this left a tiny window for the parts of the process that actually generated the most value. Things like talking to customers and deep thinking about strategy lost out to designing box art, marketing and testing.

The former, although important, could be compressed by managers, whereas the latter had fixed time scales.

Delivering software via the internet meant that there wasn't a manufacturing constraint any more. But as anyone who makes things will tell you, getting a product to a customer is rarely constrained by how fast you can put it in the box.

Making software takes time, and there are many steps a program needs to go through before it can be given to a user.

Eventually the majority of software was accessed via a browser rather than installed locally on the user's computer. That made the perfect conditions for things to change. I might be applying too much hindsight here, but it seems that the key to change was the shift in mindset from delivering software to delivering value. To drag out a tired old metaphor: "[People] don't want quarter-inch bits. They want quarter-inch holes."[1. http://rites-of-passage.com/images/Levitt_TheMarketingImagination.pdf?]

Software people who maintained services on the internet were able to see detailed analytics on who did what, which parts of the site got used, where users abandoned their searches and so on. But releases were still expensive. It took upwards of a week to deploy a new version of the software. So they did what any sensible, regular person would do in the situation; they waited. ( Quarterly releases are still a thing in some sad old-fashioned places.)

Almost all the jobs that needed to be done between the programming and the release could be automated. Because this was work that could be done using the skills and raw materials that software people had, they just got on with it! That resulted in the devops revolution.

Now, complex, automated tooling is the norm in software. Every time you press save the work of two weeks in 1998 time gets executed. This has brought cycle times down from one year (in the boxed software days) to companies like Amazon who deploy multiple-thousands of times a day.

Deployment being so simple means that new kinds of things are possible. A|B tests, staged rollouts, ultra-fast response times to market forces and current events. All this stuff is allowing software to win.

We often talk about software as it it's a thing, or at least a sector. I think it's more productive to think of it as a mindset.

So much of software ideology comes from Japanese manufacturing philosophy. They joined it onto other ideas, scavenged pragmatically from other fields and made something close to a religion based on what works!

Manufacturing and software are both on board with this, but architecture and interiors got left behind. There are predictable reasons given, and some have some merit. However I see them counting in some/most contexts, not in all.

The most common is that each project is unique. I see this as analogous to the 1970s computer salesman and army of nerds period. Whilst each project is unique, there is far more 'the same' than different between any two. If compilers were able to iron out the difference between computer systems then we should be able to systematise-away most of the uniqueness in built projects.

"The work I do can't be automated!" I have written about this before. Most people think that the work that they do is all valuable, but really the 80:20 rule[1. Pareto principle or power law.] applies (at least) and the time spent as a creative genius is far outweighed by time spent doing delegatable, and therefore automatable tasks.

Software has become so powerful because it has the means to reverse that ratio. (Often talked about as leverage.)

"Software is intangible, it takes time to do X!" This argument has far more merit. If X is to varnish some wood or wait for concrete columns to cure then it does take time. However there are things that don't take time. Every day people put up ad-hoc offices in cafes and airport lounges. Tiny nodes of major corporations that are set up and torn down in seconds. This is where I think our effort should be focused!

Enough of the ranting and onto the specifics. I'm excited about this project because it is the first viable application of the software mindset to built space. It takes infrastructure (other people's vacant real estate) and deploys a service to it. (Workplace As A Service--is WAAS too silly?) It also has the potential to scale[1. although I don't think that scaling early is necessarily a good idea. Limiting WIP and iterating fast might be better.] and be highly instrumented.

Because it'd have a low deployment and teardown time it would allow for continuous improvement (CI) based on qualitative feedback from users and quantitative feedback from sensors.

If we can get the users accustomed to continuous improvement (CI) then they would be excited to see the new physical features included in the space. Not only physical features though.

I love the idea of this being like space exploration. If we take everything with us, then like NASA we have total control.

Tesla sets a fantastic precedent for this. They push software updates to their physical product automatically. These make a difference to how a roadster handles as well as just giving new buttons to press. We can do the same, continuous deployment of improvements to the software that makes the space work better than a regular space. That would probably start with things like really good air conditioning[1. Temperature, humidity, air flow, gas composition, not just roughly controlling the temperature.] or making a standing desk set itself to the users desired height rather than pressing the buttons. These sorts of things have been the norm in luxury cars for years, it's time they were the norm in workspaces.

All of this is physical, but it would also create a longitudinal relationship with the users. Allowing us to help them to redefine how they work. Can their workspace be more than a passive part of that? This takes us into the realms of the quantified self. Knowing what you do, and what factors {which? a|e}ffect that gives people a competitive edge. We'd become an active part of their business, not just a vessel for shelter.

item.title: A quick timeline of books I've read
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.content:encoded:
I've often wondered about how much data is harvested while I read a Kindle book. It seems like a lot goes to Amazon and the authors, but I couldn't find much for myself. I've made this timeline by scraping the Kindle notes and hightlights page, then doing a little bit of sublime/spreadsheet fu.

Problems

  • It only gives date of last highlight, not of the date finished and started, so I've assumed that each book took me about a month to read
  • It won't show books where I didn't highlight anything. That might account for the reduced amount of reading when I first got a kindle.
  • I haven't finished all of the books. I've finished most of them but there are a few that are still going, or that I abandoned.
  • The books aren't classified at all. It'd be good to see how I treat different types of books. E.g. I know I usually finish fiction books in a day or two, but non fiction I drag out a bit.
If anyone can think of a better way to get at this data I'm all ears!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A quick timeline of books I've read
